question.text: While studying an autosomal recessive disorder in a family, it was noted that husband and wife both did not suffer from the disease but their fathers had the disease. What is the probability that the couple will have a girl child without the disorder?

solution.text: Husband and wife are heterozygous as they don't suffer from autosome recessive disorder but their fathers were suffering from it. Their phenotype is Aa. The cross Aa x Aa produces children in the ratio AA:Aa:aa = 1:2:1. The probability of having a child without disorder Aa or AA will be <math><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></math>. The probability of having a female child is <math><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></math>. The probability of having a female child without disorder is <math><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>8.</mn></mrow></mfrac></math>
